characters: AN EGG, CRACKING INTO A BOWL.
THE BASE OF THE SYCAMORE TREE
JULI TELLING CHET SOMETHING. CHET LAUGHS.
HOLD ON THE FRONT OF THE HOUSE
CHET AND JULI WRAPPING BRANCHES IN PLASTIC SO THEY CAN BE
ON JULI, A FEW MINUTES LATER,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful huge sycamore tree at the top of a hill somew outside Seattle, in one of the computer suburbs near Redm A moving truck is coming up the hill, followed by an SUV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moving truck pulls up in front of a very pleasant hou with a neat, manicured front lawn and some pretty flowers It’s one of the larger houses on the street. BRYCE LOSKI, 8, gets out of the passenger side of the mov van. He’s already handsome for good. His father RICK gets out of the driver’s side. Bryce and his father dress similarly. The SUV pulls into the driveway and Rick’s wife PATSY LOS and their daughter LYNETTA, 12, get out. Patsy is trim, blond, cheerful, pert, the kind of woman who is always a little too pulled-together.

dialogues.speaker: THE STREET
dialogues.text: The four Loskis walk up the front walkway to their new ho and stand there staring at it. Then Bryce turns to look a the house across the street and we hear:

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The first day I met Bryce Loski, I flipped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the upper window we see JULI BAKER, 8, looking out the window across the street. She’s a tomboy, freckled, adorable.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O., CONT)
dialogues.text: Honestly, one look at him and I became a lunatic. She throws open the window and shouts across the street.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Hi! The Loski family turns to look at the Baker house across street.  flippedldmay21 2. It’s one of the smaller houses on the street, and it’s as eccentric a house as the Loski house is conventional. It’ not exactly ramshackle, but the lawn needs cutting, there Santa Claus on the roof, there are several whirligigs in front yard and an old Toyota in the driveway. The climbin rose needs pruning. A dog is sitting on the front porch a he wakes up and barks in a kind of half-assed way as Juli throws open the window.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: (shouting) Hey, hi. I’m Juli Baker!

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Bryce, how nice. I think she’s exactly your age.

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: (up to Juli, re: Bryce) I’m Lynetta. This is my brother Bryce. Say hi, peabrain.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Lynetta, zip it.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Welcome to the neighborhood! It’s a great neighborhood! You'll love it! On Bryce:

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: (voice over) All I ever wanted was for Juli Baker to leave me alone.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: I’1l be right down! Juli slams the window shut. Rick Loski is looking at the Baker house, at the Christma decorations on the roof.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: What are we going to do about those Christmas decorations?

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: I thought you liked the Christmas decorations.  flippedldmay21 3.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: When we bought the house it was Christmas. I had no idea they kept them up all year. Rick starts toward the moving van.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: How are we ever going to sell this house if the house across the street has Christmas decorations all year?

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: We’re not selling this house. We just bought it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryce and his father are in the moving van, unloading box Juli pops up. She’s carrying her soccer ball.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Here I am. I love moving.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Who loves moving?

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: I’m great at moving.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I found out later she’s great at everything. Absolutely everything. She climbs in, agile as a monkey and begins moving boxes.

dialogues.speaker: RICK LOSKI
dialogues.text: Hey, those are valuable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rick deposits Juli out of the truck and onto the ground.

dialogues.speaker: RICK LOSKI
dialogues.text: Your mom’s probably wondering where you are.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: She knows where I am.  flippedldmay21 4. She picks up her soccer ball, kicks it elaborately in the air, drops it on the back of her foot, flips it back up i the air and catches it.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: (to Bryce) I have two older brothers, Matt and Mike, who look like twins. They have no interest in kids our age. If they seem like they’re interested in you, they’re not, they just want to torture you. Some day you'll be grateful to me for this tip.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: How was I going to get rid of this girl?

dialogues.speaker: RICK LOSKI
dialogues.text: (to Bryce) Bryce, isn’t it time for you to help your mother?

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Sure thing. Bryce jumps off the truck.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I couldn’t believe it. Dad to the rescue. He didn’t like her either. I mean, what a show-off. And my own dad was putting the ditch play in motion. Bryce starts toward the front door of his house. But Juli follows.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It was weird. I started to follow him --

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I heard her coming after me but I couldn't believe it -- Bryce looks over his shoulder, sees Juli just behind him.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I guess you’d have to say I was chasing him up the walkway --  flippedldmay21 5.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Maybe it just sounded like she was chasing me, I mean, she couldn’t be chasing me, could she? Why would she be chasing me?

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I was just trying to stop him so maybe we could play a little before he got trapped inside --

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -- and she blasted right past me grabbing my arm -- Juli passes Bryce, grabs his arm and stops him.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -- and the next thing I know he’s holding my hand, looking right into my eyes -- Hold on them. On Bryce, looking at Juli. On Juli, looking at Bryce.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My heart stopped. It just stopped beating. I mean, his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I tried to shake her off, but she just clamped on tight.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They were gorgeous. And they were staring straight at me.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She looked so sappy I couldn’t believe it.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I almost got my first kiss that day, I was sure of it.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: If my mother hadn’t come out of the door at that moment --  flippedldmay21 6.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: If his mother hadn’t come out there’s just no telling what might have happened -- Bryce’s mother comes out the front door and looks at the of them.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Well, I see you’ve met my son. Bryce untangles himself and shoots straight into the hous

dialogues.speaker: FOUR YEARS LATER
dialogues.text: Bryce is now 12 years old. He’s mowing the lawn, sitting the very latest version of an electric lawn mower.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It’s four years later, and guess what? Nothing’s changed. The only real difference is that Grandma died, mom’s mom, so Grandpa moved in. We see the front porch of the Loski house. Sitting on it CHET DUNCAN, Patsy Loski’s father, a man in his early seventies. On the table next to him is a Tom Clancy book a copy of the newspaper, but Chet isn’t reading, he’s jus sitting there. We see the Baker house. It’s slightly shabbier than it wa and there are more Christmas decorations. The grass is longer than ever.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And meanwhile I’ve still got my own personal stalker -- Up in the Baker window we see Juli, who’s now 12 too. She looks out the window at Bryce, who’s mowing the lawn.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Hey, Bryce! Good work! Bryce goes on mowing.  flippedldmay21 7. Juli’s father ROBERT BAKER pulls his battered pick-up tru into the driveway. A painted sign on the side of the truc says Robert Baker, general contractor. MATT and MIKE, Jul older brothers, who are both 16 but not twins, get out of truck with their father and start into the house.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My dad had this idea that if we did a really great job on our front lawn it might inspire the Bakers to clean up their yard, but guess what, it didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Dinner everybody! Bryce turns off the mower and starts into the house, past grandfather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Loski family is at the dinner table. Food is being passed. Lynetta, now 16, lots of eye makeup, takes a tiny portion. Bryce helps himself. Rick is eating spaghetti. N Grandpa.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Is that all you’re eating, Lynetta?

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: Could be. She breaks up a tiny piece of a pasta strand and puts it her mouth, chews it slowly.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: (calling to her grandfather who’s still outside) Dad? Dinner?

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: I think he heard you.

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: Maybe he’s not hungry. Rick and Patsy exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Don’t say it, Rick.  flippedldmay21 8.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Don’t say what? Patsy goes to the front door.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Dad? Come on. You gotta eat. Her father shakes his head no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryce in bed. Lights are out. On Bryce, listening through the wall to a barely-audible fight between his parents.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Look, he’s heartbroken.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: He should be living with people in the same situation --

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: I am not sending him to a home --

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: He hates me.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: He doesn’t hate you. Hold on Bryce, listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Bryce comes out the door. His grandfather is sitting in the chair, rocking.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Morning, grandpa. His grandfather doesn’t answer. Bryce starts down the block.  flippedldmay21 9.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The huge sycamore tree at the top of the hill. About EIGHT KIDS are standing under it, waiting for the school bus. Bryce joins them. A beat. Four of the kids ar girls, including SHELLY STALLS, another seventh grader wh hanging around with her friends. They’re all in tank tops and jeans, and lots of accessories. Most of them are wear I-Pods.

dialogues.speaker: SHELLY
dialogues.text: Hi Bryce.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Hi Shelly.

dialogues.speaker: ALL THE OTHER GIRLS
dialogues.text: Hi Bryce.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (SHOUTING)
dialogues.text: The bus is three blocks away! Everyone looks up. Juli is sitting about halfway up the sycamore tree. She can see the road.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Two and a half! Everyone stares at each other and shrugs. Typical Juli. Juli starts to shimmy down the tree. There’s a spiral sli halfway down and Juli puts her arms out into the air as i she’s flying. She lands on the ground just as the bus is block away.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: (to the group) Here’s the thing about sycamore trees, you almost never find them all bunched up together. They are individual. They do not need company. The bus stops and everyone starts to get into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryce sits down in the bus with his friend GARRETT. Juli sits right in front of him, with her friend DARLA.  On Bryce, She hands flippedidmay21 10.

dialogues.speaker: DARLA
dialogues.text: Hey, Jules --

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Hey, Darla. Bryce, do you realize that tree could be a hundred years old easily? Which means it could practically be the oldest thing in this entire town.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Here’s the deal. I always tried to ignore Juli, but she always ended up sucking me in.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: It could be two hundred years old.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: I seriously doubt that.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Well it could. determined to ignore Juli.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: (continued) It could.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: That tree is an ugly mutant tangle of gnarly branches.

dialogues.speaker: DARLA
dialogues.text: Bryce Loski, how can you say that about a tree?

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: He can’t help it. He’s visually challenged. (she pulls a sycamore leaf out of her notebook) A lot of people confuse the sycamore leaf with a maple but it’s not. the leaf to Bryce.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Keep it.  flippedidmay21 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In front of the class is the teacher, MISS BRUBECK.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BRUBECK
dialogues.text: The science fair is in six weeks -- Juli is sitting behind Bryce. Every so often Juli leans forward and takes a sniff of Bryce’s hair.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BRUBECK
dialogues.text: -- and good science projects take time. Shelly Smalls looks over at Juli leaning forward to sniff Bryce.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Here’s something I forgot to mention. On top of everything else, she liked to sniff me --

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: His hair smelled like watermelon --

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And she thought I didn’t know she was doing it --

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So I would just lean over very subtly, and I swear to God he never even knew I was taking a whiff -- Juli notices at Shelly Stalls is staring at her. She stop sniffing Bryce’s hair. Shelly smirks at her and rolls her eyes at her friend MIRANDA.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BRUBECK
dialogues.text: Shelly, do you have some problem with the science project?

dialogues.speaker: SHELLY
dialogues.text: No, Miss Brubeck.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BRUBECK
dialogues.text: So please have your projects in mind by next Monday. The bells rings.  flippedidmay21 12. Shelly looks back at Juli.

dialogues.speaker: SHELLY
dialogues.text: You know what you should do your project on? Obsession. She stands up to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is filing out of the room. Juli is gathering up things.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BRUBECK
dialogues.text: Do you have a science project, Juli?

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: No. But I will.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BRUBECK
dialogues.text: Of course you will.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Although I wish I knew what it was.

dialogues.speaker: MISS BRUBECK
dialogues.text: I have a friend who has chickens. I could get you fertilized eggs, and you could hatch them --

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: What if they die?

dialogues.speaker: MISS BRUBECK
dialogues.text: Well if you document it, you’1l still get an A, if that’s what you care about.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: I don’t care about getting an A. Miss Brubeck looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Okay I do. Miss Brubeck smiles at her.  flippedidmay21 13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juli’s mother TRINA is cooking dinner. She’s tall and pretty, wearing jeans and a pullover sweater. Juli is mak a salad, which she puts on the table. As Mike, Matt and Robert come into the kitchen:

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: I might hatch chickens for the science project. Miss Brubeck can get me eggs --

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: Why don’t you just grow beans?

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: That's like a third-grade thing.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Make a volcano.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Volcano, dude.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Volcanos are so lame. They are so “poy” .

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I could help you make an incubator.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: You could?

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: Something smells funny in here. Do you smell something funny?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner. Rick, Patsy, Lynetta, Bryce and Patsy’s father Ch Chet is not saying anything.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Whatever I do I am not doing the volcano thing.  flippedidmay21 14.

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: Why don’t you do plants?

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Plants?

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: You plant two sets of plants and one of them you talk to and the other one you don’t talk to and then you see which one grows more.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Oh sure. Me talking to plants.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: What’s wrong with the volcano thing?

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: It is so lame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are six eggs in a hygrometer, labeled Abby, Bonnie, Clyde, Dexter, Eunice and Florence. Juli is watching her father paint a landscape. The baseme is filled with painter’s supplies.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: A painting is all about light. of course, it’s also about composition, and about whatever you’re painting, but it’s the light that makes a painting more than the sum of its parts -- On Robert, painting. His brush dips into the oil paints a onto the canvas, dappling light into the landscape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynetta is getting ready to go to school, Rick is pouring coffee, Patsy reading the paper, Bryce eating breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: Okay. Here’s another idea. You put celery in red ink.  flippedidmay21 15.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Which proves what?

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: (as to an idiot) The ink turns the celery red, proving that a plant sucks up moisture. It’s like putting a flower in water.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: So why not just put a flower in water?

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: Why I bother helping you I will never know. I know, build a computer.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: What’s the Baker girl doing?

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: She is hatching eggs.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: That girl loves to grandstand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juli’s father holds one of Juli’s eggs up to a cardboard and aims a flashlight at it.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: People used to use candles to do this. Look. You can see the embryo. Juli looks. We can see the embryo.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: See the dark spot in the middle? With all the veins leading to it? We see it. It’s pulsing.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Oh my God! (shouting upstairs) Everybody! Wait till you see this!  flippedidmay21 16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the Bakers are looking at the eggs.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Bonnie’s heart is beating.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: Congratulations. You’re a mother. Trina starts up the stairs, followed by Matt and Mike.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: I still smell that smell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Trina, Matt and Mike come into the living room. Their dog, CHAMP, is peeing on the end table leg.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: Champ, what are you doing? I knew it. I just knew it. The Mystery Smell comes from the Mystery Pisser. Did you see that? Robert and Juli come up the stairs. Robert goes over to look.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: It’s barely a drop.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: Exactly. Which is why I’ve never been able to find anything. That dog stays outside from now on.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Mystery Pisser.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Cool name. They high-five each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful blue kite is flying in the sky.  flippedidmay21 17. Juli and Darla walk home from school. They’re kicking a soccer ball down the block. When they get to Darla’s hous Darla peels off, with the soccer ball. Julie continues on, and looks up to see the kite. It crashes into the top of the sycamore tree. On Juli, looking up at the tree.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I always knew the sycamore tree was the greatest tree ever. It hada built-in slide, almost a complete spiral, and it was great to ride it down. But I’d never been to the top until the day the kite got caught up there. Juli starts to climb the tree. Inside the tree, as she gets higher and higher. She looks up and there’s the kite, flashing through the branches. She looks down and realizes she’s way up in the tree. Now she looks out and sees Bryce. He’s looking up at the tree.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And then it turned out to be Bryce’s kite.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Hey, you don’t have to get that --

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I can get it --

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: It's too high, you'll fall --

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: I can get it -- She shinnies up higher. She looks around. Higher than she ever been.  flippedidmay21 18.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Hey, it’s okay, I can get another kite. Juli, you're making me nervous. Juli gulps.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: No problem. She reaches out for the kite. But the string is tangled. She untangles it. For a moment she almost loses her balan

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Break the string! Juli reaches out to break the string and grabs the kite. And suddenly she’s on top of the tree, looking out. Juli’S POV: The view is heart-stopping. A gorgeous sky in blues and violets, fluffy clouds she could float away on, sunlight dappling the tree-tops and roofs. ON JULIANA, on top of the tree turning her head to see th world from every angle. The light changes every which way she looks. WIDE SHOT: A young girl at the top of a giant sycamore tr CLOSE ON Juli: elated.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Are you okay? Juli awakens from her reverie, and starts down the tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Juli lands on the earth, holding the kite. She hands i to Bryce.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: I was on top of the world. You should have seen it. You should have seen the light. She turns and starts home, with Champ.  flippedidmay21 19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juli dances around her father as he gets out of the truck heads into the house.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: I was up so high and I wasn’t afraid. I felt like I was flying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Baker family is making dinner.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Everything sparkled, like it had just been washed. And I could smell the breeze, it smelled like sunshine --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As her father paints and Juli works on her egg chart.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: I totally understood what you meant about the sum of the parts. Dad, you’ve got to do it, you've got to climb the tree.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I think my tree-climbing days are over. There’s a noise. A little noise. Juli looks into the incubator. One of the eggs is starting to hatch.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Yow! Look at this! Can you believe this!!!  Everyone!!!!

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My friend, there is not a lot to incubating eggs. You’ve got your light, you’ve got your container, you've got some shredded newspaper, and that’s it. (continued)  flippedidmay21 20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Bryce, with his parents, walks in carrying a large cardboard tray with a mound of sand piled onto it. This i volcano.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But not Juli. It’s a miracle she didn’t turn up at the science fair in a chicken suit. At least six other boys have also made volcanos. One of t boys lights a match. The top of his volcano starts to sputter. Imitation lava flows down the side. No one is looking at that volcano or at Bryce. Nor are they looking at Shelly Stalls’ science project, w is a study of how long lipstick stays on your mouth, in comparison to lip gloss. There are fifteen large photogra of Shelly's lips. Shelly stands there.

dialogues.speaker: SHELLY
dialogues.text: Hi, Bryce. She puckers her lips at him. But Bryce is looking over at a crowd of people. They’re looking at Juli and her incubator. Tiny fuzzy chi and two little eggs cracking open ...

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Listen to this, she actually Managed to time it so the last two eggs hatched during the fair. A baby chick emerges from the shell. THE ENTIRE GROUP OF SPECTATORS: AWWWWWWWW.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: How does a person do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juli stands on stage in front of a row of judges. She has her incubator and a huge bulletin board with photos and diagrams. She has a laser pointer.  flippedidmay21 21.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (with disdain) And yes that is a laser pointer. To light this diagram or that part of the incubator or this section of the chart and talk about how unbelievably exciting -- Bryce, eyes narrowed, watches...

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: (to the judges) It was unbelievably exciting --

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -- it was to watch eggs grow for twenty-one days. ON THE AUDIENCE, watching. Juli’s parents and Matt and Mi so proud. Juli’s friend Darla watching too.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And guess what? The audience bursts into applause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mrs. Brubeck pins a blue ribbon on Juli.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That's right. She won first prize.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: And I want to thank mom who is such a great supporter, my amazing Dad, who helped me build the incubator, and my brothers who did nothing -- The audience laughs. On Bryce, not laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryce is carrying his volcano out of the school. comes up to him.

dialogues.speaker: SHELLY
dialogues.text: Your lava was great, Bryce -- Shelly  flippedidmay21 22. Bryce tosses the volcano into a dumpster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juli comes outside. Darla is helping her carry the incubator. Everyone congratulates Juli. Her parents and brothers are waiting.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: But those go back to Mrs. Brubeck, right?

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Are you kidding me?

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: They’re coming home?

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Where else would they go?

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: Darla could take them.

dialogues.speaker: DARLA
dialogues.text: My mom would kill me. DARLA’S MOM appears. DARLA’S MOM I would. I would kill her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they get out of the van and walk into the house.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: But where are we going to raise chickens?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: In the yard. They’re very low maintenance. They eat bugs. The family goes into the house.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So that’s how we wound up with chickens. (continued)  flippedidmay21 23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six chickens in the front yard.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O., CONT.)
dialogues.text: But what none of us thought of was that six chickens scratching for bugs not only gets rid of bugs, it also tears up grass. So pretty soon there was nothing whatsoever left of our yard. (continued) We see there’s almost no grass left in the yard. Across the street, we see Bryce, mowing the perfect Loski lawn.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O., CONTINUED)
dialogues.text: And I’m sorry to say this, but chicken feed attracts mice. (continued) We see Matt and Mike, setting out some very simple mousetraps.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O., CONTINUED)
dialogues.text: So my brothers decided, as long as we've got mice, might as well get a snake. Snakes love mice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Trina Baker goes up the stairs. Hold on the stairs as hear her open the door to Matt and Mike’s room. She screa

dialogues.speaker: TRINA, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: What is a snake doing in this house? Were you planning to tell me about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The snake is now living in a large aquarium in the garage Matt, Mike and Robert are showing it to Trina.  flippedidmay21 24.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Trina, it will be fine. Boa constrictors are really no trouble at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trina is working at her computer as Juli comes into the r

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Mom, guess what? She holds out her palms. Eggs.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: No. Honey, no. No more chickens, please I can’t take this.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Not chickens, eggs. Just eggs.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: Eggs.

dialogues.speaker: AN EGG, CRACKING INTO A BOWL.
dialogues.text: Cracking into a bowl. A PLATE OF SCRAMBLED EGGS ... It's passed around the table, everyone oohing and ahhing about how great they taste.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: There is nothing in the world like a fresh egg.

dialogues.speaker: A PLATE OF DEVILLED EGGS
dialogues.text: Robert pops one into his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: These are as good as my mother’s devilled eggs.  flippedldmay21 25.

dialogues.speaker: A BOWL OF EGG SALAD
dialogues.text: As Robert heaps egg salad onto his plate.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Love egg salad. Love it.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: Good thing you do. AN EGG IN SOMEONE’S HAND ... INT. SKYLER BROWN’S GARAGE - ANOTHER DAY There’s a lot of rock and roll stuff -- guitars, drums, amplifiers and an upright piano. Lynetta stands in the garage with an egg in her hand. Ona table is the boa constrictor. Next to her is her boyfrien SKYLER BROWNE. A group of friends, including Juli’s brothers Matt and Mike watch. Skyler steps up next to Lynetta.

dialogues.speaker: SKYLER
dialogues.text: To the riddle of which comes first, we have an answer. The egg comes first. Lynetta waves the egg theatrically in the air. Bryce comes into the garage, looking for Lynetta. Matt sp him.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Bryce, my man, just in time for the Skyler and Lynetta Show.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: (to Lynetta) Mom wants you.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Give the baby bro a front row seat. Come on, don’t be shy, step right up ... ON BRYCE, shoved into the front. Bryce’s mouth gapes open when he sees the snake.  flippedidmay21 26.

dialogues.speaker: SKYLER
dialogues.text: Lynetta, the egg please. Lynetta holds up the egg as if she’s the magician’s helpe displays it this way and that, locks lips with Skyler and then hands the egg over to him. Skyler hands the egg to Mike.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Here’s where I come in. (to the snake) Ready? ON BRYCE WATCHING as ... Mike gives the egg to the snake, which opens its mouth wi and ingests the egg whole. WE CAN SEE THE EGG IN THE BOA’ NECK. ON BRYCE, FREAKED. AND THEN THE BOA SWALLOWS A SECOND EGG. AND THEN A THIRD EGG. On Bryce, completely disgusted.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: So Brycie boy, how is he going to digest this? He needs a tree or a leg. (leaning in close) Want to volunteer yours? Everyone laughs. Mike releases the snake to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Aww, too bad. He’s got another idea. He’s going to use the piano instead. The snake slithers over and wraps itself around the piano leg.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Shhh, everyone, here goes. Everyone watches. The snake stops moving, then flexes. THE SOUND of the egg crunching inside.  flippedidmay21 27.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (theatrically) Dinner is served. CRUNCH CRUNCH CRUNCH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryce and Lynetta walking home.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: So sick.

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: So cool --

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: I’m never eating an egg again. THE SOUND OF A DOORBELL RINGING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Bryce opens the door. Juli is standing there with a ha carton of eggs.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: You know my chickens? From the science fair?

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: (how could I forget them) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: So these are for you and your family. She hands him the eggs.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Oh. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The half-carton of eggs is on the table. Everyone is havi a kind of informal breakfast -- Bryce, Lynetta (whose mak from the night before is sort of running from her eyes), Patsy, Rick and Chet. Chet is reading the newspaper.  flippedidmay21 28.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Scrambled? Fried?

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: I’m having cereal.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: More coffee dad? Chet barely responds. Patsy pours more coffee in his cup.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: (back to Bryce and the eggs ) What about soft-boiled?

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: Bryce is never eating another egg. Because of the snake --

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: What snake?

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: (as if it’s common knowledge) There's a snake living across the street at the Bakers’, a boa constrictor --

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Across the street? Living across the street?

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: -- he’s kind of the mascot for the guys’ band. Mystery Pisser.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: That’s the name of the snake?

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: That’s the name of the band.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: What kind of parents would let their children name a band something like that? It’s vile.  flippedidmay21 29.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Their house is worth more because they’re across the street from us and our house is worth less because we're across the street from them. They all look at the carton of eggs. Patsy picks one up, turns it around.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: What if you cracked it open and there was a chick in it?

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: Ewwww. She puts it back into the carton. He shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: I’m having cereal.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: To be perfectly honest, I’ve never been entirely sure how an egg gets fertilized. (he laughs) I know I should know. I know roosters have to be involved. Birds do it, bees do it, but how do they do it?

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Do they have sex with the hens?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Well they must. A pause at the table. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: They must. Chet looks up from his newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: As with all birds, there has to be mating for fertilization to occur. (continued)  flippedidmay21 30. Chet is speaking. Everyone is riveted. CHET (CONT’D) Although it’s not particularly romantic. The rooster picks a hen, usually on the basis of proximity, grabs her by the back of the head, climbs on her back, and you can pretty much figure out the rest. The whole thing takes about 15 seconds give or take, and as far as anyone can tell, the only satisfying thing about the encounter as far as the hen is concerned is that afterwards she fluffs up her feathers. (beat) In any case, there are no roosters at the Bakers, I will swear to it. If there were roosters, we would know. You can hear roosters.

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: Cock a doodle doo.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: (so pleased that he’s finally said something) Grandpa! Chet goes back to his newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: I’m having seconds on cereal.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Well it’s easy to find out if there are roosters. Just ask Lynetta to ask Juli’s brothers.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: What are their names again?

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Matt and Mike. Or get Lynetta to get Skyler to ask them.

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: Shut up, Bryce.  flippedidmay21 31.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: What did I do now?

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: Haven't you noticed I haven't been going down there, jerk?

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Since when?

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: Since yesterday. Lynetta burst into tears.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Did something happen with you and Skyler?

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: Like you care. She leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Oh boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rick and Bryce are putting golf balls. Chet is on the bac porch.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Why don’t you just ask Juli Baker?

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: I’m not asking her anything.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: (from the porch) They have no rooster.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Just ask her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Bryce and his friend GARRETT come down the back alley the fence behind the Baker house. They look over it.  flippedidmay21 32. A mess. Much worse than the front yard. There’s a makeshi chicken coop and a few old pieces of lawn furniture. Cham the dog is asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juli opens the back door and comes out of the house. She’ carrying a basket to gather eggs. Garrett and Bryce duck down behind the fence. As Juli gets down on her hands and knees and dives into t chicken coop. The hens fly out of it.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: No rooster.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: Correctomundo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back at the dinner table.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Anyway, you guys can eat the eggs, but there’s no way I’m going to touch them, so don’t even ask.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Why’s that?

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: There’s poop all over the place.

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: Gross.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Chicken turds everywhere. Lynetta stands up and leaves the table.

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: You expect me to eat after this?

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Lynetta. You have to eat something.  flippedidmay21 33.

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: No I don’t! She leaves the room and sticks her head back in.

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: Does the word salmonella mean anything to you? She splits again.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Do you think the eggs could have salmonella?

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: They're probably packed with it. One bite -- (he grabs his neck and pretends to gag to death)

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I can’t believe you didn’t just ask her. You are afraid of that girl.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: She just bugs me. She bugs you too.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Just take back the eggs and tell them we don’t eat eggs. Tell her we're allergic to them, or something.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Well that would be a lie. You want him to lie?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: That’s not the point. The point is, he spies on someone’s yard instead of asking a simple question. On Chet, looking at Rick. Clearly he thinks Rick is bully Bryce.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (to Chet) What is it?  flippedidmay21 34.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Nothing. Chet looks back down at his plate.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (back to Bryce) Just tell her, no eggs. I expect you to look that girl square in the eye. DOORBELL RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So this is me, looking her square in the eye. Bryce opens the door for Juli. She hands him some eggs. He can hardly look at her.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And this is me, telling her “No Eggs.”

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Thanks, Juli. He closes the door. On Bryce. Mortified. He turns around and we hold on him with his back to the door, holding the eggs. Now what? We hear his parents’ door open upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I’1l be back about six. As his father starts downstairs, Bryce quickly goes into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the door to the trash below the sink, stuffs the eggs into it.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: See there were so many eggs that I had to give them away. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: flippedldmay21 35. JULI (V.0O.) (cont'd) To the Loskis, and to our our next door neighbor Mrs. Stueby --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Juli brings her some eggs.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O., CONT.)
dialogues.text: Who started paying me for them. Two dollars a dozen.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. STUEBY
dialogues.text: Nothing like free-range eggs.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And then Mrs. Stueby told Mrs. Helms --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Juli drops eggs off to MRS. HELMS, who also pays her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Juli crosses the street.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O., CONTINUED)
dialogues.text: And when I brought the eggs to the Loskis, it was so great -- As Bryce throws open the door again.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Because it was like Bryce was looking forward to me coming.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I dreaded it --

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And he always said, “Thanks, Juli” -

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Thanks, Juli.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -- Like he really really meant it --  flippedidmay21 36.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I sounded so fake I couldn’t believe it --

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The best, shiniest eggs went straight to the Loskis, and in return I got a few moments alone with the world’s most dazzling eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I could hardly even look at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More eggs being stuffed into the wastebasket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juli, wearing her school backpack, comes out of her house with some eggs.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And then something happened that changed everything and it had nothing to do with eggs. (continued) EXT. STREET —- DAY A gorgeous day. Juli walks toward the sycamore tree and t bus stop, where several kids are waiting for the bus.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And it happened on the most beautiful day, which just goes to show you that terrible things can happen when you least expect them -- She drops her backpack, jumps onto the lowest branch and climbs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Juli climbs through the highest branches to her perch the very top. JULI’S VIEW - GLORIOUS.  flippedidmay21 37. On Juli, savoring the morning, the sunlight, the breeze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darla’s at the base of the tree, as well as Shelly Stalls There’s a slightly dorky boy, JON TRULOCK.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (UP IN THE TREE)
dialogues.text: What a morning!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryce and Garrett and a couple of other kids walk down th street to the bus stop.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: The sun is sending streaks of fire from one end of the world to another! Bryce and the other kids look at each other. Typical Juli Suddenly two big trucks pull into the bus stop, and FOUR WORKMEN get out.

dialogues.speaker: ONE OF THE KIDS
dialogues.text: You can’t park there, that’s the bus stop --

dialogues.speaker: WORKMAN
dialogues.text: Sure we can.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (FROM UP IN THE TREE)
dialogues.text: Hey, that’s the bus stop -- The workmen look up at the tree.

dialogues.speaker: WORKMAN
dialogues.text: Is someone up there?

dialogues.speaker: WORKMAN
dialogues.text: Who’s up there?

dialogues.speaker: JON TRULOCK
dialogues.text: Juli Baker.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: (shouting down) -- So move your truck.  flippedidmay21 38.

dialogues.speaker: WORKMAN
dialogues.text: Is she crazy?

dialogues.speaker: JON TRULOCK
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SHELLY
dialogues.text: Yes, actually she is.

dialogues.speaker: WORKMAN
dialogues.text: Well, this tree’s coming down, so she’s got to get out of it.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: The tree’s coming down? What do you mean the tree’s coming down?

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: I mean the tree’s coming down. (calling up to Juli) Hey, girl. You gotta come down from there.

dialogues.speaker: WORKMAN
dialogues.text: How did she get up there?

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: She climbed.

dialogues.speaker: DARLA
dialogues.text: Juli, they’re tearing down the tree!

dialogues.speaker: JON TRULOCK
dialogues.text: They’re serious! Two workmen take chain saws out of the truck. ON Juli, on top of the tree ...

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: (shock) This tree? The sycamore tree?

dialogues.speaker: WORKMAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, whatever, it’s going. Come on down.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: They have chain saws.

dialogues.speaker: DARLA
dialogues.text: Huge ones.  flippedidmay21 39.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: (shouting down) Who said you could? Who gave you permission?

dialogues.speaker: WORKMAN
dialogues.text: (shouting back) The owner, that’s who.

dialogues.speaker: DARLA
dialogues.text: (also shouting up) The owner.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: (shouting down) He has no right!

dialogues.speaker: WORKMAN
dialogues.text: (shouting up) He’s building himself a house and he can’t very well do it with this tree in the way. Now, come down from there, we got work to do.

dialogues.speaker: DARLA
dialogues.text: (shouting up) The owner’s the owner. In the distance, the school bus is coming.

dialogues.speaker: SHELLY
dialogues.text: Bus is coming.

dialogues.speaker: DARLA
dialogues.text: Juli, the bus is coming.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: No. No, I won’t. You can’t cut it down, you just can’t! This tree is a historical landmark! On the workmen, looking at each other, what is going on?

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: She loves the tree.

dialogues.speaker: WORKMAN
dialogues.text: Spare me.

dialogues.speaker: SHELLY
dialogues.text: She’s bananas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: flippedidmay21 40.

dialogues.speaker: WORKMAN
dialogues.text: (calling) Come down from there.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: (to the workman) Can I speak to you privately?

dialogues.speaker: WORKMAN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: (quietly) If you cut down the tree, it’1l be like cutting out her heart. That tree is, like, 200 years old.

dialogues.speaker: WORKMAN
dialogues.text: Your girlfriend’s a nut.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: She’s not my girlfriend --

dialogues.speaker: WORKMAN
dialogues.text: (shouting up to Juli) I’‘1l call the police. Do you want me to call the police?

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: (shouting back) I don’t care!

dialogues.speaker: WORKMAN
dialogues.text: I’m calling them. We've got papers here -- (he waves them)

dialogues.speaker: DARLA
dialogues.text: (shouting to Juli) They have papers. They’re going to arrest you. It’s going to go on your college application.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: I’m not coming down from this tree! I’m never coming down! as the school bus arrives.  flippedidmay21 41.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: You’re going to have to cut me down ! All the kids waving at her to come down: Juli, come down, Juli, please, you’re going to get in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Juli, they mean it. Come down.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: (calling to her friends) No, you come up! All of you! Darla, everybody! If we’re all up here they can’t cut it down! ON THE KIDS, looking up at her. Jon Trulock is clearly to

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Juli, I can’t climb that tree --

dialogues.speaker: DARLA
dialogues.text: Me either.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: (pleading) You don’t have to climb this high. Just a little ways. Haven’t you ever heard of civil disobedience? The BUS DRIVER gets out of the school bus.

dialogues.speaker: BUS DRIVER
dialogues.text: Are we going to school or what? A couple of the kids start toward the bus. Darla is stricken. Bryce is torn.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Please. Please. Oh man -- One by one, the kids get on the bus. Bryce is last.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Bryce, please, if you just come up here, we can save it -- Bryce gets on the bus. The bus takes off.  flippedidmay21 42. Juli, on top of the tree, watches the bus pull away. Workman #1 takes out a cell phone to call the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chet Duncan is sitting on the front porch, reading the pa We hear the sound of a siren. Chet looks up. As he does, two police cars pass, then a fire engine. Chet stands. A LOCAL NEWS TRUCK passes. Chet walks out to the street and starts walking. As he walks, Trina hurries past him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chet among a crowd of neighbors, firemen, newsmen, news trucks, the workmen. Trina is on her cellphone, trying to reach her husband.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: (to Rob’s message) I can’t believe you're not answering. Call me when you get this message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert Baker is supervising as raw wood is being loaded i his pickup. The sound of a buzz saw cutting planks drowns out the sound of his cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some workmen and firemen are attempting to reason with Tr

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: It's something that my daughter feels very strongly about.  flippedidmay21 43.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: (shouting down) I’m not coming down, Mom!

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: (shouting back) That’s what I told them. ON JULI, in the tree. SUN GRADUALLY SHINES EVEN MORE BRIGHTLY as we head toward noon.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCASTER
dialogues.text: It’s been three hours, and Juli Baker is still up in that tree, refusing to come down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A truck pulls up, delivering pizza. The crowd is bigger. Chet is still there, as is Trina. A florid man in an expensive suit -- the OWNER of the property -- gets out and begins conferring with police. LONG SHOT OF JULI, fierce and brave and defiant, at the t of the sycamore. Trina, once again on the cellphone.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rob, having unloaded the lumber, is talking to a mason at construction job he’s supervising. There’s a small cement mixer that drowns out the ring of the cellphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rob drives the pickup truck on a two-lane highway. He tur on the radio. MATT’S VOICE (ON RADIO) Our sister’s impossible. MIKE’S VOICE (ON RADIO) Stubborn.  flippedidmay21 44. MATT’S VOICE (ON RADIO) A nightmare. MIKE’S VOICE (ON RADIO) But we back her a thousand per cent! On Robert. What?

dialogues.speaker: RADIO BROADCASTER
dialogues.text: As of now, Juli Baker has been at the top of the sycamore tree for six hours -- On Robert, floored. He makes a U-turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd is larger. Matt and Mike continue to give interviews to anyone who’s interested. Maybe Mike mention their band, Mystery Pisser. There’s a ice cream truck. Ch is eating an Eskimo pie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juli sits defiantly on top of the tree. She’s adjusted he position so she’s very comfortable, straddling a large branch, leaning back against the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert Baker pulls up in his pickup truck. He looks up at the tree. There’s Juli. She sees him. On Juli, in the tree. She looks down. She sees him.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Dad! They want to tear down the tree!

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: (calling up to her) So I hear. Several newscasters attempt to waylay him, but Robert ign them. He puts his arm around his wife and they begin conferring with the Police Chief.  flippedidmay21 45.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: If they’re taking this tree, they’re taking me with it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There’s a huge cherry picker next to the tree and the che picker-operator is guiding the top of the vehicle. EXT. TOP OF THE TREE —- CONTINUOUS Robert Baker is up in the cherry picker, talking to Juli, who’s eating a sandwich he’s apparently brought up with h Chet watches from below.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: It’s not your tree, honey --

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: It’s everyone's tree.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Well unfortunately it’s not. It’s that guy’s tree. The one with the red face, who’s jumping up and down like Rumpelstilskin -- Looking down at the crowd looking up into the tree, we se the owner, who looks furious.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: And judging from my recent introduction to him, the environment is not at the top of his list of priorities --

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Look at this view. No one’s ever going to see this view if he cuts down the tree -- Robert nods. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I know. I’m in complete agreement with you. A beat.  flippedidmay21 46.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: But what?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: But what if you’re still up here in the middle of the night, and you fell asleep and fell out of the tree? Juli and her father looking at one another.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No view is worth my little girl’s safety. Another beat. The sun is starting to set. And then Juli suddenly vanishes. She slides down the tree for the last time. She comes down the spiral slide and holds out her arms as she’s flying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lands.

dialogues.speaker: ON JULI, A FEW MINUTES LATER,
dialogues.text: speaking to a television news reporter with a cameraman.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: I just believe that the tree belongs to all of us. When something is that old and that beautiful and everyone respects it and expects to wake up in the morning and see it every single day, then it’s not just one person’s tree, it’s everyone’s tree. ON Chet, watching her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juli gets into the truck with her father.  flippedidmay21 47. They drive away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the first chain saw start to buzz. Juli bursts into tears.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Hey, hey. He pulls over. He tucks his hand under her chin so she looks at him. Tea stream down her face.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I’m so proud of you. She buries herself in her father’s arms and sobs her hear out.

dialogues.speaker: THE BASE OF THE SYCAMORE TREE
dialogues.text: The tree is mostly gone. Bryce and some friends walk past on the way home from sch The whole landscape has changed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire family is watching the local news.

dialogues.speaker: JULI ON TV
dialogues.text: Just because you own something doesn’t mean it’s not part of what makes a neighborhood a neighborhood As we hear a newsman say: Juli Baker, a young woman who t a stand for what she believes in ...

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I’m glad you didn’t get involved in that, Bryce. Bryce feels awful that he didn’t.  flippedidmay21 48.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: They're attention-getters. That whole family. Chet stands up and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (to Patsy) Your father hates me.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: He doesn’t hate you, he loves you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Chet sits in his rocker, reading the newspaper. Bryce comes outside, sits down next to his grandfather. The two of them sit there.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Did you read this? We see now a picture of Juli on the front page of the newspaper, with a huge picture of the sycamore tree and a headline: A LOCAL GIRL’S FIGHT FOR A SYCAMORE TREE.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: I don’t have to read it. I was there.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: A girl like that doesn’t live across the street from everyone.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: A girl like that is a big mixture of things --

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Most people are mixtures of things. (he hands him the newspaper ) Read this. Without prejudice. Bryce takes the newspaper. He’s irritated. He stands goes into the house. up and  flippedidmay21 49. INT. BRYCE’S BEDROOM - NIGHT As Bryce comes into his bedroom carrying the newspaper. H stuffs it into the bottom drawer of his desk. Throws himself on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Juli’s window. The curtains are drawn. INT. JULI’S BEDROOM - NIGHT She’s on the bed, weeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two houses opposite each other. A sad, lonely night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big hole where the sycamore was. Kids wait for the bus. Juli’s not there. The bus pulls up, they get on.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: From then on, she refused to ride the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juli mopes through the halls. She passes Jon Trulock.

dialogues.speaker: JON TRULOCK
dialogues.text: I’m really sorry about the tree, Juli. Juli nods. Bryce at a locker, watches.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She stopped charging around, stopped lecturing kids on throwing their trash in the garbage.  flippedidmay21 50. A kid drops garbage in front of her. She steps over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juli stares out the window.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No more slicing the air with her hand, dying to be called on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juli eating with Darla. Bryce comes toward her with his tray.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I kept thinking I'd say something, like, Man, sorry about your sycamore, but nothing came out. He walks on by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryce on the bus. Looking out the window, he sees Juli, i rain slicker, pedalling her beat-up bicycle.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Even in the rain, she wouldn’t ride the bus.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: Weird, huh.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Juli’s weird. EXT. JULI’S HOUSE - DAY Bryce, outside, mowing the lawn He keeps sneaking looks a Juli’'s window

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: She even stopped watching my every move. Which was a total relief. CAMERA TRAVELS THOUGH JULI’S WINDOW...  flippedidmay21 51. INT. JULI’S BEDROOM She’s lying on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Juli comes out the back door with a basket to collect eggs. Champ is lying on the back porch. Juli leans down to give him a nuzzle. Champ is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Champ is being buried. Robert, Trina, Matt, Mike, Juli an some of their friends. There’s a tombstone that says: “He lies Champ, the Mystery Pisser.” Matt and Mike and Skyler are singing a heavy metal song a Champ, a dog that inspired a great music group. The last spades of dirt are shoveled over the grave. Juli is blowing her nose into a handkerchief. The song ends. Wide shot on:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Robert pulls up in his truck, gets out. A puppy jumps out of the truck, barking. Trina opens the front door.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: Oh, Robert.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Don’t even bother saying no -- They look at each other. No real difference of opinion.  flippedidmay21 52.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Juli, honey, come on down here, I’ve got a surprise -- Hold on a wide shot of the house. The front door is open we see Juli come down the stairs. The puppy leaps into Juli’s arms and starts to lick her f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juli, carrying a half-carton of eggs, comes up the walkwa with her new dog LUCY. Bryce whips the door open before she rings the bell.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Cute dog.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Her name’s Lucy. I know it’s very common but I couldn’t help it. She hands him the eggs.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Thanks. Are you going to start riding the bus again? Juli shrugs. An awkward moment. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: You don’t have to give us these.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Well. Thanks. He closes the door. Juli sort of stands there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryce walks with the eggs to:  flippedidmay21 53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trash can is absolutely full. He tries stuffing the eggs into it. They barely fit. He rummages around and tries to poke them down into it. He pulls out the whole trash bag. Then he walks toward the front door, carrying the trash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Bryce comes out the door carrying the trash. We can hear the garbage truck coming up the block. Suddenly Bryce sees Juli. She’s still on the porch, refastening Lucy’s leash.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Hey --

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Hey -- He starts down to the street. The trash bag is heavy. He gets to the curb, Juli following. He stuffs the trash bag into the garbage container that’s on the street for the garbage truck pickup. The egg carton pokes out. Juli can see the eggs through the holes in the carton.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Why are you throwing the eggs away? Did you break them?

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Yeah and I’m really sorry about that. She opens the carton. All the eggs are there, intact.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Why are you throwing them away?  flippedidmay21 54.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Does the word salmonella mean anything to you?

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Salmonella?

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: My mom doesn’t think it’s worth the risk. The garbage truck arrives in front of the house and empti the trash bags into the back of the truck. Juli is just standing there, stunned, as the noise of the garbage truck makes conversation temporarily impossible. The truck pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: So that’s basically it. Bryce starts back toward his house. Juli follows him. She looks funky.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Salmonella?

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Your backyard is like, covered in turds. I mean, look at your place Juli. Just look at it. It’s a complete mess.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: It is not.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Oh come on, Juli. Look at it. over at the house. It happens to look particularly

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Have you always thrown the eggs away?

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Look, we didn’t want to hurt your feelings.  flippedidmay21 55.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: My feelings? People pay me for these eggs. They pay me two dollars a dozen --

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: They do?

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you just give them back to me? Why didn’t you just come up with a polite excuse like, we don’t want your stupid eggs. I was just being ... neighborly.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Yeah, well if you really want to be neighborly look at your yard. It’s a freak. People on this block have lawns. Every single house. And you know what? It’s May. Who has Christmas lights all year long?

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: You don’t like our twinkle lights? Are you nuts? Twinkle lights make you happy. There’s no law that says you have to take them down in January. Downtown Seattle is full of twinkle lights.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) And Santa Clauses, everybody’s got Santa Clauses all year long. (throwing her line back at her) I mean, just because you own something doesn’t mean it’s not part of the neighborhood. You said that yourself, Juli, on TV.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: I hate you, Bryce Loski, I absolutely hate you. She turns around walks back over to her house. Lucy the d follows.  flippedidmay21 56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the window, we see Chet watching the two of them. He’s obviously overheard the conversation. As Bryce starts back to the house, he sees Chet watching. Chet vanishes from the window.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I couldn’t believe it. I wasted like four years of my life on Bryce Loski and he turned out to be the worst human being on the planet. (continued)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Juli walks into it and the door closes. Hold on the fr of the house. It is a mess, no question.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O., CONTINUED)
dialogues.text: What made me the craziest was that I could sort of see what he was talking about. I mean, not everything. But I could see that someone looking at our house might think it looked sort of shabby ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juli is sitting at the table, lost in thought. Everyone e is passing food around.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: Your Uncle David is coming again this summer.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: How’s Uncle David?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: The same. Exactly the same.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Top of the Space Needle --  flippedidmay21 57.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Man, I never saw anyone made so happy by a Space Needle. Juli comes out of her reverie.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Do you think a person can be less than the sum of their parts?

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: I don’t think that’s a kind way to talk about Uncle David, Juli.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: I wasn’t talking about Uncle David.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: We were talking about Uncle David's annual visit.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Are we taking him to the Space Needle? The Bakers exchange looks -- where has she been?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Of course we’re taking him to the Space Needle. Juli stands up and walks over to the front window, looks at the lawn.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Do we have, like, clippers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juli is going down the aisle pushing a basket with her mother.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: I was thinking that it wouldn’t be hard to fix up the front yard. It could be, you know, a project. A summer project.  flippedidmay21 58.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: That’s a huge undertaking. Once I decided to alphabetize the books in my parents’ house and I didn’t even get through the B’s.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: But it looks so bad.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: It does? INT. JULI’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Juli is in bed, reading a book on landscaping. There’s a knock on the door. Trina and Robert open it.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Juli, did something happen? This revelation about our house --

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Nothing, Daddy. Both parents sit on the bed. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Something happened.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: The Loskis have been throwing my eggs away because our yard is so filthy they think they'll get salmonella if they eat them --

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: That is ridiculous --

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: Did Patsy say that?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: They are such snobs.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Do you realize we’re the only people on this entire block who don’t have grass?  flippedidmay21 59.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: Well, we used to have grass --

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: But then we had chickens --

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: So it’s my fault we don’t have grass? She bursts into tears.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: Of course it’s not your fault, honey. Even when we had grass our yard was ...

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Eccentric. We are eccentric.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: I know, I know. Juli still weeping.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: Oh, honey --

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: That silly woman with her DKNY purse. Trina looks over at him.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: She’s not so bad. She helped me jump-start the car once --

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Whatever.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: Since when do you know about DKNY purses? He shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I keep up.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: Not to mention that uptight father in those idiotic alligator shirts.  flippedidmay21 60. They both start to laugh. Even Juli is cheering up.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: You really want to clean up the yard?

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: I do. It’1ll still be eccentric, I promise. (beat) They hate the Santa and the twinks too.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: They hate twinkle lights? Oh, they are really sick.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So a couple of weeks later, summer vacation begins --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Bryce and Garrett come bicycling down the street toget

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O., CONTINUED)
dialogues.text: And I’m coming home from buying a hundred pairs of socks for camp, and there she is -- Juli, dressed in jeans and an old shirt, is hacking away the shrubs in her yard. Bryce turns into his driveway and Garrett bikes on.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (talking to the shrubs as she hacks away) Out of there ... yes! ... you are coming off whether you like it or not ...

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She’s cleaning up the yard. Like I didn’t feel bad enough for what I said but now she’s shoving my face in it... Bryce walks into his house, passing his grandfather on th front porch.  flippedidmay21 61. INT. BRYCE’S BEDROOM - A FEW MINUTES LATER He’s sitting at his computer, but he can hear her whackin and ranting.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And does she do it like anyone else, like a normal person? No, she’s talking to the shrubs -- He slams the window shut. INT. BRYCE’S BEDROOM - LATER He’s lying on his bed, reading a magazine. He can still h Juli through the window.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So then I find myself thinking, should I help her? Probably. I mean she’s all alone, it’s a pretty big job -- (continued) He gets up and walks over to the window ...

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O., CONTINUED)
dialogues.text: So I thought maybe I’d go out there, maybe I'd make it up to her by helping her cut back some bushes. Period. End of story. If she still wanted to be mad at me after that, fine. Her problem. (continued) INT/EXT. VIEW OUT BRYCE’S WINDOW - CONTINUOUS His grandfather is crossing the street to talk to Juli. H carrying some garden tools.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O., CONTINUED)
dialogues.text: But I never got the chance. ON BRYCE AMAZED. INT/EXT VIEW OUT BRYCE’S WINDOW ... Julie and Chet. Chet takes garden gloves out of his back pocket, puts them on and together they tackle the hedges.  flippedidmay21 62.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: There’s my grandpa doing my good deed. My grandpa. Who'd been parked on our front porch in a pair of bedroom slippers for six months, and now, thanks to Juli Baker, he’s in work boots. He’s walking. He’s talking. Had I ever seen him smile? The guy’s smiling. A series of shots: CHET AND JULI CUTTING BRANCHES.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: All week long it went on. INT. BRYCE’S BEDROOM - DAY Bryce at his computer. The sound of whack, whack, whack. EXT. JULI’S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS As Juli hammers nails into the fence, with Chet next to h EXT. BRYCE’S BEDROOM WINDOW - CONTINUOUS As Bryce goes to the window and looks out at the two of t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Chet sees Bryce in the window, looking out at them. Ch waves at Bryce.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Hey, there -- Juli looks up, just in time to see: EXT. BRYCE’S BEDROOM WINDOW - CONTINUOUS As Bryce disappears out of sight, mortified.  flippedidmay21 63. EXT. BRYCE’S HOUSE - ANOTHER DAY A taxi pulls up. Bryce’s father RICK gets out with a suitcase and his golf clubs. He notices Chet and Juli working across the street. Walks into the house.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So now it’s my last night before camp, and my dad’s just gotten home from some conference about computer interfaces --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner time. Rick, Patsy, Lynetta, Bryce and Chet. Chet i eating heartily.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Patsy, this is delicious.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Bryce’s favorite dinner. (to Bryce) Because you are not going to get food like this at camp.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: You all packed?

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Almost, almost.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: So they basically broke us up into buzz groups but they kept changing the mix, so just when you thought you knew where you were, you weren’t --

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: How fascinating.

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: Boring.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: That’s rude, Lynetta. Chet helps himself to another serving.  flippedidmay21 64.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (to Chet) So, Chet, I had no idea you were in the mood for a home improvement project. A beat. Bryce notices that Chet is pointedly ignoring his father.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Pass the salt, will you Patsy?

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That was the first time I wondered, Maybe grandpa isn’t too crazy about Dad --

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: So why’s the girl the one who's finally doing something about their place? ON CHET, salting his potato, taking his time about it. He looks up at Bryce.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The big stare. Man oh man that freaked me out. Was Grandpa going to tell Dad about how I ragged Juli about the yard? ON CHET looking at Bryce, who’s now sweating. Then he loo at Rick.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: She wants to, is all. Chet again looks over at Bryce and then goes back to eati Bryce, relieved, wipes his face with a napkin. INT. BRYCE’S BEDROOM - LATER In the bedroom is his camp trunk, about half-packed. His grandfather comes into the room. Bryce comes out of the closet, with some tee shirts to pa

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Hey.  flippedidmay21 65.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: (surprised) Hey. Chet sits down on Bryce’s bed.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Look, I know I messed up. I should have told her the truth about the eggs, and then she caught me tossing them out and I just lost it. (beat) Thanks for not saying anything at dinner. I owe you big time. His grandfather gets up, walks to the window, and looks o across the street.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: She reminds me of your grandmother.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Juli? Bryce waits. Finally Chet turns around.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Your character is set at an early age, Bryce. The choices you make now will affect you for the rest of your life.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Don’t yes-sir me.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Here. Everyone needs a little money to get through camp. He hands Bryce some money. Bryce is stunned, looks at the money.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Thanks.  flippedidmay21 66.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: The next time you’re faced with a choice, do the right thing. It hurts everyone less in the long run. He leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryce and his dad carry his trunk out to their SUV. They it into the back of the car. Bryce looks up at Juli’s window. She’s not there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert drives his truck past the place where the sycamore tree used to be. There’s a man in the front seat of the truck with him -- his brother DAVID, 41, who has Asberger syndrome. We see David look over at the house going up on the property.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juli is seeding the lawn in front of the house as Robert pulls into the driveway and he and Uncle David get out.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE DAVID
dialogues.text: Hi Juli --

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Uncle David --

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE DAVID
dialogues.text: Your tree’s gone. You were sad. Uncle David gives her a sweet, awkward hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
