dialogues.text: The Baker family eats a barbecue dinner outdoors with Unc David. Uncle David is counting his baked beans.  flippedidmay21 67.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Baker family, including Uncle David, going up in the Space Needle elevator. Uncle David is compulsively counti floors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juli and Chet are planting tulip bulbs in the garden. Dav counts them. Mrs. Stueby turns up from next door with a t of lemonade for everyone and a big smile for Chet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert, Juli and David approaching the corner where the sycamore tree used to be.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Don’t drive past where the tree was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the truck makes a left turn to avoid going past the intersection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juli and Robert drop Uncle David back at the sanitorium w he lives. Everyone gives him hugs goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE DAVID
dialogues.text: Too bad about your tree, Juli.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Thanks, Uncle David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Juli through her window.  flippedidmay21 68. INT. JULI’S BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS Juli in bed, reading. A knock on her door. Her father pee in...

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Hi, Dad. He sits on the edge of her bed.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I always liked that tree of yours, even before you told me about it.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Dad, it’s okay, I'll get over it.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: No, it’s not okay, and you don’t have to get over it. Listen to me, just listen -- (beat) I want the spirit of that tree to be with you always. I want you to remember how you felt when you were up there and the whole world sparkled. (beat) My brave daughter looking out at the world from the very top --

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: It was so beautiful, and now it’s as if it wasn’t even there --

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I know. Robert goes back to the door, and brings a canvas in from hall.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: That's why I made this for you. ON JULI’S FACE as she sees: A wonderful painting of the sycamore tree. And way up in the top, a young girl lookin out into the distance.  flippedidmay21 69.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: My tree. My sycamore tree. ON JULI, overwhelmed with feeling. She throws her arms around her dad.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Oh, Daddy, thank you. Thank you. INT. JULI’S BEDROOM - MORNING She’s asleep. The sun starts to come up outside. Juli opens her eyes. Across from the bed is the painting, with a shaft of morn light illuminating it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juli comes out the front door.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Oh my god! There’s just the tiniest fringe of grass starting to spro on the lawn.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: We have a lawn!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Trina and Juli, both with their faces pressed to the ground, look through the grass.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: My lawn!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A barbecue. Matt, Mike, Juli, Trina and Robert. There’s a tray of devilled eggs, which only Robert is eat

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: I just think we should talk about it. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: flippedidmay21 70. JULI (cont'd) I mean, it’s all very well for me to be making unilateral decisions where the appearance of our house is concerned --

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (making fun of her big word) Oh, unilateral --

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: But we are a family.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: She’s right. We should talk about it. There are basically two separate --

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: And yet linked --

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: -- questions.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Well I’m not taking the Santa Claus down .

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: Okay. So much for Question Number One.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: So Question Number Two is --

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: The twinkle lights.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Well I personally have strong feelings about the twinkle lights --

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Moi aussi.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: (good-natured) Oh shut up.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I’m not kidding. I do.  flippedidmay21 71.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: So do I.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: So that probably makes five of us with very strong feelings about the twinks. He flips the hamburgers.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: I was thinking ... Robert leans over and gives her a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: What were you thinking, love of my life?

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: I was thinking the problem with the twinks -- Everyone leans forward ...

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: Is we need more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All five Bakers, at work on the front of the house. They’ hanging twinkle lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Loski SUV drives into the Loski driveway. Bryce gets out. He’s suntanned, and it looks as if he’s grown three inches. He looks over at the Baker house. His father gets out of car. They start to unload Bryce’s trunk.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: It looks amazing.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Except that damned Santa Claus is still up on the roof.  flippedidmay21 72.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt is looking out the window.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: The asshole is back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The curtains are drawn. Juli, Matt and Mike are in the living room. Mike is looking through binoculars, out the window.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW THROUGH BINOCULARS
dialogues.text: Through the Loskis’ bay window across the street: We can the dining room, with the table set for dinner. Patsy bri a big salad to the table and the family starts to come in sit down.

dialogues.speaker: MATT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They're coming in to dinner.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: One second, bro.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: They’re sitting down. You ready?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Hit it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside, a boom box blasts Bruce Springsteen’s “Santa Clau Coming to Town” at ear-splitting levels toward the Loski house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone freezes as they hear the music. They turn to the window.  flippedidmay21 73.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Juli, flipping a switch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Loskis get up from the table to look out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rick, Patsy, Bryce, Lynetta and Chet stare out the window Their POV:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole place is lit up. The front lawn, bushes, fence, doors, windows -- twinkle lights galore, wrapped around everything. ON THE LOSKIS, STARING. On Chet starting to smile.

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: How cool is that. On Bryce:

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I’m not going to tell you that I spent the whole time at camp wondering if Juli was still going to be mad when I got back, but it did cross my mind. And then I get back and I realize she’s not just mad, we're at war.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: What’s this supposed to mean?

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: I think it’s just a big welcome home for Bryce. Chet and Bryce look at each other.  flippedidmay21 74.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the kids going to class, hanging out. Everyone looks more grown-up.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Everything changed in eighth grade.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Everything changed in eighth grade. Juli and Darla walking down the hall, looking at boys.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Boys. Bryce and Garrett walking down the hall, looking at girls

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Girls. Shelly Smalls, who has continued to triumph over adolesce bats her eyes at Bryce.

dialogues.speaker: SHELLY
dialogues.text: Hi, Bryce.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Hi, Shelly.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I kept hoping Juli would soften up a little, but she just cut me dead - Juli and some friends walk past Bryce, who looks after he she walks down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It was a big relief not to be thinking about Bryce, ‘cause it gave me a lot of extra time to focus on the important things, like school -- We see the eighth grade homeroom teacher, MISS SIMMONS.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We had a new teacher. Miss Simmons.  flippedidmay21 75.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: New teacher. Really great.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Really tough.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Very stylish.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Kind of weird-looking.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SIMMONS
dialogues.text: All right, everyone, clear your desks of everything but a pen or pencil. The class is shocked. Is it a pop quiz? What’s going on? Miss Simmons picks a stack of yellow papers off her desk, fans herself and says.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SIMMONS
dialogues.text: It's time to vote for basket boys! She starts passing out the papers.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) Who wants to be a basket boy?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SIMMONS
dialogues.text: You do, Garrett. It’s an honor to be a basket boy. We’re electing twenty boys from the class --

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: I do not want to be one of them --

dialogues.speaker: MISS SIMMONS
dialogues.text: Well, you should. Basket boys are a tradition that has helped support this school since it was founded, in 1983. It’s why we have flower beds. It’s why we have shade trees and apple trees. Visit another school sometime and you’1ll begin to realize what a little oasis our campus is.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: All this from the sweat and blood of basket boys --  flippedidmay21 76.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SIMMONS
dialogues.text: What did you say, Bryce?

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Nothing, Miss Simmons.

dialogues.speaker: SHELLY
dialogues.text: (loud whisper) I’m voting for you, Bryce.

dialogues.speaker: MISS SIMMONS
dialogues.text: Bryce, some day when your children go to school here, you'll understand. Bryce rolls his eyes at Garrett. He looks at the ballot. He looks over at Juli. She’s ignoring him and looking straight at her ballot.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I read down the list. There were 158 names, and twenty of them were going to be basket boys and auctioned off like sides of beef to pay for some flowers. But I realized that to me, there had only ever been Bryce. But I certainly wasn’t going to vote for him. I just couldn’t. What if I didn’t choose anybody? What if I just turned it in blank?

dialogues.speaker: MISS SIMMONS
dialogues.text: And don’t even think about not voting or you will get detention.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So I voted for the boys who weren’t jerks or clowns, but were just nice. Like Jon Trulock, who was really sweet -- We see Jon Trulock again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the class files out, handing in their ballots.  flippedidmay21 77.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: And then I handed in my ballot and pretty much forgot about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner. Rick, Patsy, Lynetta, Bryce and Chet.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: You should have seen all the girls looking at these ballots like it was so important they were voting for president of the United States.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: I will make a lovely basket lunch for the lucky girl who buys you.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: It’s for a good cause, Bryce.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Someone's going to buy me! He bangs his head down on the table.

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: Only if you win.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: I’m not being conceited here when I tell you I’m probably going to win - - I'm being realistic. Patsy starts to clear the plates and Bryce and Lynetta br theirs into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynetta is following Bryce around, making kissing sounds.

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: There will be a bidding war. Blood will be shed over this boy, mark my words. Chet and Rick come in, clearing their plates. There’s a c on the table in the kitchen and Rick hovers around it.  flippedidmay21 78.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Just hope that Juli Baker doesn’t buy you.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Worse things have happened.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: You’ve developed quite a soft spot for that girl, haven't you, Chet? Why on earth?

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: I have, haven’t I? She reminds me of Renee.

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: Grandma?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (disbelief) She reminds you of your Renee?

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Her spirit reminds me of Renee.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (contemptuously) Her spirit. I don’t see that. An awkward moment. Everyone knows Rick is hellbent on a fight with Chet.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Now who wants cake?

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Me.

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: Me.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Lynetta? I’m shocked. You’re eating dessert?

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: Forget it, I changed my mind.  flippedidmay21 79.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (to Chet) What I don’t understand is why you have the energy to befriend a complete stranger when you’ve never done so much as toss a baseball around with your own grandson ...

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Take it easy, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (to Chet) Have you ever talked to Bryce? Been to his room? Have you ever sat on your own grandson’s bed and had a conversation with him?

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: He has --

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: The night before I went to camp.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: So once. Patsy takes a pint of vanilla ice cream out of the freeze

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Who wants a la mode?

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: I do. Chet walks out of the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Don’t you want cake, Grandpa? There’s a beat. Chet walks back into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: You know why the Bakers haven’t fixed up the yard until now?  flippedidmay21 80.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Why? Sure. They’re trash. They've got a beat up house, two beat-up cars and a beat-up yard. They have absolutely no pride in how they present themselves to the rest of the world.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Juli's father has a retarded brother.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: David. At Greenhaven.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: And it’s very expensive to keep him there --

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Well that certainly explains everything --

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Rick --

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: That’s the reason they never kept the yard up? They’ve got two perfectly healthy boys over there who could have mowed the lawn all these years. Just because there’s a retarded relative someplace .... Rick stops, suddenly aware that everyone is looking at hi horrified.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (exploding) I’m not going to feel guilty for saying this. I’m not. Chet walks out of the kitchen. Everyone looks at each other. Suddenly we hear the front door slam.  flippedidmay21 81. Lynetta dumps her ice cream in the trash. Walks out. We hear her bedroom door slam. Patsy puts her cake down and walks out. A beat. Her bedro door slams. On Bryce and his dad.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Well, at least one member of the family is on my side. Bryce couldn’t be more miserable. INT. BRYCE’S BEDROOM - LATER Bryce is lying on his bed, staring into space. A pebble hits his window. He goes to the window, looks out and sees Chet in the fro yard. He opens the window.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Want to take a walk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Chet and Bryce walk down the street. A beautiful fall night. We hear the sound of an owl.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: That is the Western screech owl. Chet imitates the sound. The Western screech owl makes its cry again.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: No big deal. I learned it all when I was a kid. Your mother knows all the bird sounds.  They pass tree used They stop They look flippedidmay21 82.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: She does?

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Well she used to, anyway. No telling what she knows now. the house under construction where the sycamore to be. and Chet looks up into the night.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Must have been a spectacular view. up at the starry night sky.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: You probably know all the constellations too.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Yep. I do. You probably know the Big Dipper. End of story.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Nailed. (beat) Did you ever see her up in the tree?

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: The day they took the tree down. It scared me she was up so high. But after I read the article I understood why she did it. The tree’s gone, but she’s still got the spark it gave her. Know what I mean? They start on.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: As we see Chet and Bryce walking together.  flippedidmay21 83.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: I was engaged to be married to someone named Geraldine McCarthy, oh yes, they’d sent out the invitations and they even had one of those bridal showers deals, I remember someone gave us a big plate from Marshall Field with asparagus painted on it, that was the idea, you used the plate just for asparagus. God forbid you should put a string bean on it. Geraldine got so angry at me when I broke off the engagement and she had to return all the presents including the asparagus plate, but I couldn’t help myself because I’d met Renee and I couldn’t very well get married to anyone else once I did. Of course then I had to prove to Renee I was worthy of her because I'd wasted all that time with Miss Asparagus Plate.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: How did you do that?

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: A grand gesture. I made a grand gesture. They come to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Renee would have sat up in that tree all night long. (beat) Well. This is where I get off. Bryce looks around.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: I promised Susannah I’d drop by for some coffee.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Stueby?

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Don’t wait up.  flippedidmay21 84. Chet starts toward Mrs. Stueby’s, leaving Bryce. Bryce is floored. Chet rings the doorbell at Mrs. Stueby’s and Bryce starts home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Bryce, coming up the stairs to the front porch. He's silhouetted against the Christmas lights on the Baker hou INT. BRYCE’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Bryce comes into his room. His room is in semi-darkness, only by the Baker twinkle lights. He opens the bottom desk drawer and takes out the creased scrunched newspaper. He turns on his desk lamp, illuminating the article and picture of Juli. The rest of his room stays in semi-darkn

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So finally I read the article. They called her “a strong voice in the urban wilderness,” “a radiant beacon, shedding light on the need to curtail overdevelopment.” I couldn’t help thinking about my part in the whole business -- not that you could call it a part exactly --

dialogues.speaker: THE SYCAMORE TREE
dialogues.text: Bryce at the school bus, with Juli in the tree, begging h to help her.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Bryce, please, if you just come up here, we can save it. Bryce gets on the bus. END FLASHBACK. INT. BRYCE’S BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS BRYCE, on the bed, reads on...  flippedidmay21 85.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Juli said, “To be held above the earth and brushed by the wind. It's like your heart has been kissed by beauty.” Who talks like this? Bryce looks at the photo of Juli in the newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I kept looking at the photo of Juli. On the photo of Juli in the newspaper: It’s a close up of her at the top of the tree, taken with a telephoto lens.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She’s looking off in the distance and the wind is blowing her hair back like she’s at the helm of a ship or something, sailing into the sun. ON BRYCE, staring at the photo.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I'd spent so much time avoiding Juli Baker that I’d never really looked at her, and now all of a sudden, I couldn’t stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patsy makes coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Bryce comes downstairs. He looks into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rick is asleep on the couch, under a quilt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryce comes in and reaches for a box of corn flakes.  flippedidmay21 86.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: I have come up with a solution for our situation. We’re going to invite the Bakers over for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: We are? Does Dad know?

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Yes. And the Baker kids too, of course. Juli and the boys. What are their names?

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Matt and Mike. Does Grandpa know?

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: I can’t seem to find your grandfather this morning. He must have been up early. Lynetta comes into the kitchen. She’s wearing a mini-skir platform heels, and eyes made up like raccoons.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: I thought you and your friends were going to church this morning.

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: We are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trina is talking to Robert. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Friday night?

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: All of us.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Oh man. You think they think we’re all going to be pals now that we cleaned up the yard?

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: I have no idea, but she was insistent. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: flippedidmay21 87. TRINA (cont'd) She was practically in tears, saying how sorry she was she’d never invited us before and how she'd really like to know us better. Juli comes into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: The Bakers have invited us all to dinner.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: No way.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Way.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Bryce Loski is my mortal enemy. They all laugh.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: I’m not kidding. He’s disgusting, shallow, immature, revolting --

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: I couldn’t really say no. She once helped me jump-start my car. And after all that help Chet’s been to you --

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: They’re just asking us over so we'll take down the twinkle lights. That’s probably the whole purpose.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: It sounded more like a let’s-be- friends deal.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Let’s not be friends.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: (relieved) Oh, Daddy, thank you. Thank you, thank you, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: We are going. I said yes.  flippedidmay21 88.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryce is walking down the hall, Juli is coming toward him She pretends he doesn’t exist. As he turns to watch her, crashes right into Mrs. Brubeck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the teacher talks about something like the Civil War, Bryce goes into a reverie, staring at Juli. ON DARLA, looking at Bryce looking at Juli. INT. GYM — DAY At one end of the basketball court, Juli and a group of g shoot baskets. At the other end Bryce is shooting with some boys. He looks over and Juli dribbles toward the basket and lea into the air. Juli’s hair flows backward, as if it’s windblown, she loo exactly as she did in the newspaper, as if she’s on top o the tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryce leans on his elbow and pretends to read but manages contort himself practically into a pretzel to watch Juli she moves around the library. FROM THE STACKS ...

dialogues.speaker: DARLA
dialogues.text: (a whisper) Psst. Juli. Juli doesn’t hear. Darla tosses a lipstick at her. Juli goes over and huddles in the stacks with Darla.

dialogues.speaker: DARLA
dialogues.text: Bryce is bonkers over you.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: (horrified) Bryce Loski?  flippedidmay21 89.

dialogues.speaker: DARLA
dialogues.text: Like there’s another Bryce -- The boy is positively lost in Loveland. Look at him.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Look at him? Shoot me first. Darla literally turns her that direction. Bryce has his hands over his eyes with his fingers slight separated so he can stare at Juli. Quickly he closes his fingers and looks down at his book. Darla cracks up.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: I have to go dinner there tonight.

dialogues.speaker: DARLA
dialogues.text: I bet you’re the dessert, girl. Mmmm mmm.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: (laughing but horrified) Stop it. She looks at Bryce, who’s still watching her, now from underneath his book. Panic: They both look away. Bryce pretends he’s really stretching.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: I’‘1l just tell my mom, I can’t go. It's just completely out of the question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juli comes home from school. She sees fresh pies on the kitchen counter.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But I couldn’t refuse to go, I just couldn’t because you know what, my mom was just so happy. She walks by her mother’s room...  flippedidmay21 90. INT. TRINA & ROBERT’S BEDROOM -- CONTINUOUS Trina deciding which blouse to wear. Juli looks in.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: Which one?

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Both great. (as she goes toward her room) I’m not dressing up.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: Patsy and I agreed on dress up. She’s making risotto.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Oh, whoa, risotto. INT. JULI’S ROOM - A FEW MINUTES LATER All her clothes are out on the bed. She’s finishing getti dressed. She’s unexpectedly stylish -- a big sweater over little T-shirt with a long scarf wound around her neck. S looks at herself in the mirror. Then she picks up an eyelash curler and curls her eyelash

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trina, Robert and Juli in the kitchen. There are two pies the kitchen table.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Two pies?

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: Not everybody likes pecan. Matt and Mike turn up in the kitchen. They’re both wearin jeans and T-shirts. Both T-shirts have the name of the ba on it, “Mystery Pisser.”

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: Absolutely out of the question. They pivot sharply and leave the kitchen to go upstairs t change their T-shirts.  flippedidmay21 91. EXT. BRYCE’S POV: THE BAKER FAMILY CROSSES THE STREET. The doorbell rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Chet opens the front door. Bryce is scrambling downstairs, still buttoning his shirt Patsy is behind him. Matt and Mike walk in the door. High-fives.

dialogues.speaker: MATT AND MIKE
dialogues.text: (to Bryce) Hey, baby brother, how's it going? Lynetta appears, looking like a nocturnal rodent.

dialogues.speaker: MATT AND MIKE
dialogues.text: Hey, Lyn. Lookin’ good. Lots of shaking of hands and introducing. Lynetta, Matt and Mike disappear upstairs to Lynetta’s ro as Rick Loski appears and shakes hands with everyone. Bryce and Juli suddenly together.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Drinks everyone?

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: (to Bryce) I’m here because my mom really wants to be here, but don’t get any ideas that we’re friends. We are not friends. She walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON BRYCE, by himself. Robert and Chet are talking about perpetual motion machin Juli is listening. Rick comes in with a tray of drinks, offers them around.  flippedidmay21 92.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: That yard of yours has come along. I told Chet here we ought to hire him out. Is this a joke? Everyone smiles uncomfortably as Rick pic up the tray of canapes.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Now who’s for hors d’ouevres? On Bryce, watching his father be a total phony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone’s at the table. The food is being passed around. Bryce is sitting across from Juli.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: So guys, you’re seniors this year.

dialogues.speaker: MATT AND MIKE
dialogues.text: Amen.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Amen? In like you’re glad school’s almost over?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: The regurgitation gets to you after while.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Isn’t that funny? High school was probably the best time of my life.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Seriously, Dude. It’s so bad. Trina shoots Mike and Matt a look.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Well it is, Mom. It’s that whole robotron attitude of education -- confine, confute, conform. (xe the food: lets the word roll off his tongue) So this is risotto. No wonder it’s famous.  flippedidmay21 93.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (to Matt and Mike) So you're not thinking of college? ON BRYCE, his father is really embarrassing him. He looks over at Juli. Juli looks up from her plate, sees Bryce looking at her, looks quickly back down again.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I’m applying early admission to Brown and Mark’s hoping for U Dub --

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: But we’ll probably give the music thing a shot first.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Oh, the music thing.

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: Dad, your sarcasm is not appreciated.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (to Robert) How do you feel about that, Robert?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I learned a long time ago that I have very little power over my children. So if they want to try the music thing, they try the music thing --

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: The band’s really good, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I’m sure they are.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: No they are. Sometimes they remind me of Husker Du, sort of indie rock but you can’t really put them ina category -- On Mike and Matt, pleased. On Juli. She can’t help liking Bryce a little.  flippedidmay21 94.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: (to Lynetta) Where’s the CD? He stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryce sticks a CD in Rick’s elaborate stereo system, hits play and cranks up the volume. BLASTING INTO THE ROOM: Matt and Mike’s music. lLynetta starts dancing and singing along to a Mystery Pisser song Everyone listens to the song, and Lynetta goes wild, danc The song ends. lLynetta grins at everyone and punches the out of the stereo.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: It’s okay if you don’t like it but it’s what we do.

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: I could listen to it again and again and again. It’s great.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: You must write down the lyrics for me.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Just one song?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: We've written a ton of songs, there’s just three on the demo.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: You have a demo? Demos are expensive. Studio time’s expensive. I know ...

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: When Rick and I met, he was playing in a band -- Lynetta chokes on her water and has to be patted on the b

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: Dad? You were in a band? What'd you play? Clarinet?  flippedidmay21 95. She cracks herself up.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: No, honey, your father played guitar.

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: Get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Country.

dialogues.speaker: MATT AND MIKE
dialogues.text: Dude! Total respect, man.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: And when our band tried to get a demo made, it was astronomically expensive. So how’d you afford it?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: We found this guy on the Internet --

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: He was blowing out his old analog gear for digital.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Digital is weak, don’t you think? You lose too much of the waveform. Everyone stares at Chet.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: They've been saving pennies since they were twelve.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (to Rick) You still play? We could lay down some of your tunes if you want?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: No thanks. That’s not me anymore.  flippedidmay21 96.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bakers are leaving. Matt and Mike are carrying home t left-over pie plates with some left-over pie. Lots of goo byes and hugs and thanks. Juli says goodbye to everyone. Chet gives her a big hug a then she’s faced with Bryce. They stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: (at the same time) I’m sorry. They’re embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: I shouldn’t have said that about not being friends. Your mom made such a nice dinner.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: I shouldn't have said anything about your house, I mean, it’s your house, it was really rude, and I didn’t realize why it was such a mess. Juli looks at him, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean, your Uncle.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: My Uncle?

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Because you know, it costs so much where he’s staying and you couldn’t afford to keep the yard up.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Because of Greenhaven and everything.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Oh man, oh man, that is so completely -- She’s almost inarticulate --  flippedidmay21 97.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: What did I do now?

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: That's not the reason we didn’t keep the yard up. We don’t believe in things being ... all perfect and manicured ...

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Hey, I didn’t mean anything. I can’t believe it, we’re right back where we were, doesn’t matter what I say --

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: You just don’t get it. You are never going to get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert, Trina, Matt, Mike and Juli finishing the pies.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Intrinsically limited genes.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Nothing much you can do about it.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Complete jerk.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: He was really grilling us.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: I’m not talking about Mr. Loski. I’m talking about Bryce. (trying to figure it out) Chet must have said something about Uncle David being here. And then Bryce figured out this stupid explanation...

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Maybe Chet got confused.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Not possible. Chet would never ever come up with anything like that. It’s Bryce. Aaaaaaah.  flippedidmay21 98.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Hey, he compared us to Husker Du.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: Aren't you being a little hard on him?

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: No. A look among family members.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You used to like him.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: I was wrong, okay? But now I’m right.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: I feel sorry for Bryce. Having a father like that.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Bryce is exactly like his dad.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: You sure of that?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Of course she is.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: She’s sure of everything.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: I am. What’s wrong with that?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Nothing. Just checking.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (looking at his own dad) Not everyone's lucky like us. In the Dad area. Tears well in Robert’s eyes.  flippedidmay21 99.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: Who wants milk?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Just thinking that. Juli goes over to hug her father. Matt and Mike come in f a four-way hug as Trina gets the milk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Loskis clean up from dinner.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: That was a delicious dinner, Patsy.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Thanks, Dad. It was fun, wasn’t it? Those boys were nothing like what I expected. Matt and...

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: Mike. Rick comes into the kitchen with some coffee cups.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: They’re probably drug dealers --

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: No other way they could afford that recording gear. “Saving pennies” —- Trina and Robert are out to lunch if they buy that story --

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: They don’t take drugs.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: They don’t, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I know musicians.

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: You don’t know anything, Dad, but you never shut up. You’re an asshole.  A silence. flippedldmay21 100. Rick slaps her, across the cheek. Lynetta is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: You hit me? You hit me? She runs from the room upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: LYNETTA
dialogues.text: I don’t believe it. Her door slams upstairs. On Chet. She walks She slams

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Rick, how could you?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Did you hear what she said to me? My own daughter. My own daughter called me an asshole. He moves out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Well I don’t blame her. What right do you have to judge people like that?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Bryce, go on up to your room --

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: He doesn’t have go anywhere. out of the kitchen and starts upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: (shouting from the stairs) Just because you couldn’t afford to record a song 200 years ago, you think anyone who can is a drug dealer? I just knew you’d manage to ruin everything tonight. her bedroom door. Rick looks at Bryce. Together again.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Your mother and her dinner parties.  flippedldmay21 101.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: They’re not drug dealers.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: And I don’t get that you hit Lynetta. I don’t get that.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Well I was mad. Bryce walks out of the kitchen, leaving Rick. A beat. Bryce walks back into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: You want everyone to be just like you. You can’t stand it when people aren’t just like you. Everybody isn’t just like you.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Exactly. Which is why this whole evening was such a stupid idea. Rick is furious. He picks up a platter from the counter a hurls it at the wall. It shatters. Shards on the floor, food everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Big mess, Dad. Bryce walks out of the kitchen, passing Patsy, who’s comi back. INT. BRYCE’S BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS As Bryce closes the door to his bedroom. Lynetta is crying in the room next door. His parents are shouting downstairs. He sits down. Hold on Bryce.  flippedldmay21 102.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And now for some good news. It will probably not surprise you to hear that I was elected basket boy. EXT. SCHOOL —- DAY As Bryce comes up the steps to the school, he passes a ga of girls. “Congratulations, Bryce.” “Congratulations.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The names of the twenty basket boys are posted on a bulle board. There’s Bryce’s name. Darla is standing there reading it with two friends, LIZ and MACY as Juli comes up.

dialogues.speaker: DARLA
dialogues.text: Juli, Bryce is on the list -- Juli looks at the list.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Like I care.

dialogues.speaker: MACY
dialogues.text: Shelly is holding a bake sale to raise money to bid for him --

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Is that true?

dialogues.speaker: DARLA
dialogues.text: No, it’s just a joke.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Jon Turlock? How did he get on this list? Who do you suppose voted for him?

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: I did. He’s nice.

dialogues.speaker: MACY
dialogues.text: Well I guess you better bid for him

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: I’m not bidding on anyone.  flippedldmay21 103.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patsy mixes mayo into chicken salad as Bryce sits there. There’s a

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Do you think I should prepare this chicken salad as a sandwich or just as a salad? (answering her own question) Sandwich. Lettuce and tomatoes? Yes or no, Bryce?

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mom was so into it.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Pickles. Potato chips. Cole slaw.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She was just so thrilled that maybe her son was going to get auctioned off to the highest bidder. carrot cake.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: And of course my famous carrot cake.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Which wasn’t famous. Patsy starts to pack the lunch into a straw basket.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I didn’t want to break the news to my mom, but no one cares what’s in the lunch. It wasn’t like girls were bidding on the basket. When you got right down to it, this was a meat market.  flippedldmay21 104.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryce comes out of his house, carrying his basket. He’s w Patsy. They get into the van. As the van pulls away, Juli comes out of her house on her bicycle. She starts down the block.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. STUEBY
dialogues.text: (waving) Juli -- She hurries to stop Juli. Juli stops.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Hi, Mrs. Stueby. In Mrs. Stueby’s house, Juli sees Chet at the breakfast table. He waves at her. She’s a little startled, but she waves back. Mrs. Stueby hands her a wad of bills.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. STUEBY
dialogues.text: Here, dear. Take this. I’m so sorry it’s taken me this long to get it to you. I keep missing you in the mornings. Eighteen dollars exactly.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: That’s okay, you don’t have to pay me for the eggs. She stuffs the cash into Juli’s pocket.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. STUEBY
dialogues.text: No arguments. I owe you for weeks. Take the money and go get yourself a rooster.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: A rooster?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. STUEBY
dialogues.text: You need a rooster. The chickens aren't laying enough. She goes back to her house.  flippedldmay21 105.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: But I don’t want a rooster --

dialogues.speaker: MRS. STUEBY
dialogues.text: Everyone should have a rooster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryce, mortified, is carrying his basket down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: Don’t you look cute?

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: You're bitter, admit it.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: Shelly and Miranda are fighting over you. They’re having a knock down drag out. The two hottest girls in the class -- Shelly Stalls comes around the corner with Miranda. both screech with excitement when they see him.

dialogues.speaker: SHELLY
dialogues.text: Money, honey. Yes!

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: You’re all mine, baby.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: I’m not worth it, I’m really not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They All the basket boys are seated on stage. Everyone in the audience is whistling and hooting. There’s a banner over the stage that says something like: Redmond Booster Club. In the audience we see Juli sitting with Darla. MRS. MCCLURE, head of the Booster club, is at the podium.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCCLURE
dialogues.text: Welcome to the twenty-fifth annual Basket Boy Auction! Let me just remind you -- this is a civilized proceeding. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: flippedldmay21 106. MRS. MCCLURE (cont'd) No whistling, catcalls or other degrading behavior will be tolerated -- There’s another immediate outbreak of whistling and catca but Mrs. McClure takes it all in good humor.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCCLURE
dialogues.text: Minimum bid is ten dollars, and of course the sky’s the limit. As you know, the winners and their basket boys have the rest of the school day off. All right then! Our first basket has been brought by Jeffrey Bishop. JEFFREY BISHOP stands up.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCCLURE
dialogues.text: Step right up, Jeffrey. Don’t be shy. (reading from an index card) Jeffrey has brought a scrumptious lunch consisting of tuna salad sandwiches, oriental noodles, baby grapes, iced tea and fortune cookies. All right then. Do I hear ten? The bidding begins.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I was Basket Boy number nine. Which meant I had to wait on stage while nearly half the guys got auctioned off. Minimum bid, ten bucks. And if nobody bid, a teacher was secretly assigned to bid on you. Yes, friends, the possibilities for mortification were endless. As TIM PELLO is being auctioned off.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Tim Pello was basket boy number five, and his mom actually bid on him. We see MRS. PELLO jumping up and down in the audience.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PELLO
dialogues.text: Twenty! I'’11 give you twenty!  flippedldmay21 107.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Although luckily Tim was saved from everlasting humiliation by Kelly Ann Trott, who bid twenty-two fifty for his gourmet lunch of cold Big Macs. A montage of two or three more Basket boys being auctione off, with girls in the audience shouting bids that range about fifteen to twenty-five dollars. Jon Trulock gets up to be auctioned off. Mrs. McClure is reading the contents of his basket lunch.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Jon Trulock was all that stood between me and the auction block.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCCLURE
dialogues.text: (reading from the index card) -- Do I hear ten?

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -- and it took me a second to realize no one was bidding on him -- On Juli and Darla.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: What's happening?

dialogues.speaker: DARLA
dialogues.text: No one’s bidding.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCCLURE
dialogues.text: This lunch is delicious. There are strawberry tarts in it.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Poor Jon. This is all my fault. I voted for him.

dialogues.speaker: DARLA
dialogues.text: You can’t be the only one who did --

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: But I feel terrible. He’s so nice. Juli takes her money out of her pocket and counts it. Her hand shoots into the air.  On Bryce. flippedldmay21 108.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Ten.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCCLURE
dialogues.text: Ten! Did I hear ten!

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: (to Darla) Say twelve!

dialogues.speaker: DARLA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Don’t worry. I'11 outbid you.

dialogues.speaker: DARLA
dialogues.text: Twelve!

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: DARLA
dialogues.text: Sixteen!

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: I’ve only got fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: DARLA
dialogues.text: Is that true?

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: No. (raising her hand to bid again) Eighteen. (to Darla) But that’s really all I’ve got.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCCLURE
dialogues.text: Eighteen going once, going twice. Sold! For eighteen dollars. Stunned.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I couldn’t believe it.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCCLURE
dialogues.text: Step right up, Bryce Loski. Don’t be shy!  flippedldmay21 109.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I felt like I’d been slugged. Did Juli like Jon? He steps up. The bidding begins immediately -- before Mrs McClure even begins to list what’s in Bryce’s basket.

dialogues.speaker: SHELLY
dialogues.text: Ten!

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCCLURE
dialogues.text: Whoa! You don’t even know what’s in this basket.

dialogues.speaker: SHELLY
dialogues.text: I don’t care! On Miranda Humes.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Everything started to go crazy, but I wasn’t even there. I just couldn’t believe it. Juli bid on Jon. How was it possible?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Twenty.

dialogues.speaker: SHELLY
dialogues.text: Thirty. Everyone in the audience reacting.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Forty-five.

dialogues.speaker: SHELLY
dialogues.text: Fifty!

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCCLURE
dialogues.text: Wow! This is certainly impressive. Bryce, this is really something --

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It was really something. It was awful. It was even more embarrassing than selling for twelve dollars. The kids are now going “Bryce, Bryce, Bryce, Bryce” as th bidding continues up. Sixty. Seventy-five.  flippedldmay21 110.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And then suddenly, when I thought it couldn't get any worse, it did. Jenny Atkinson put in a bid. JENNY ATKINSON, a very tall girl in a basketball jersey stands up.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: One hundred dollars! On Juli and Darla, amazed.

dialogues.speaker: DARLA
dialogues.text: Good thing you weren’t interested in bidding on Bryce.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: I know. God.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCCLURE
dialogues.text: Well! This is an all-time record. And such a generous donation to the Boosters. On Bryce, ready to die.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: Bryce! You rule! On Shelly and Miranda, now standing together.

dialogues.speaker: SHELLY
dialogues.text: One twenty-two fifty --

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: We'll give one twenty-two fifty --

dialogues.speaker: SHELLY
dialogues.text: The two of us --

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCCLURE
dialogues.text: You’re pooling your resources?

dialogues.speaker: SHELLY
dialogues.text: Yes. Everyone looks over at Jenny. She’s out of the bidding.  flippedldmay21 111.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MCCLURE
dialogues.text: Well! Amazing! Sold to these two beautiful young ladies for an all- time record of one hundred twenty two dollars and fifty cents. A huge cheer goes up from the audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The basket couples parade into the Multi-Purpose room and find tables. Juli and Jon walk to a table, sit down and start talking.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It was a little strange meeting up with Jon and walking to the Multi- Purpose room for lunch, but I think he was grateful I'd bid, so by the time we got situated at the table, I wasn’t feeling awkward or silly. It was just lunch. Bryce enters escorted by Shelly and Miranda, one on each side.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The whole thing was demented. Shelly and Miranda are jumping around, waving at everyone

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -- Shelly and Miranda were acting like they’d won the lottery. Shelly and Miranda escort Bryce to a table, dive into Bry basket, divide things up, fight over them, yak at Bryce.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It would have been easier if I hadn’t been seated in direct view of Bryce and his little harem. (beat) But I did my best to ignore them. She turns her focus more intensely on Jon, smiles at him. Bryce looks across the cafeteria --  flippedldmay21 112.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Then I saw Juli. She was looking at Jon, her eyes all sparkly and laughing. What was she laughing at? ON JULI, listening to Jon.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Jon told me a really funny story about building a radio-controlled airplane from scratch and practically setting his basement on fire -- Back to Bryce:

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And meanwhile Shelly and Miranda are talking about suntans and how important it is to tan evenly. Juli laughs at something Jon says. Bryce looks back over at her.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: How could she sit there and look so beautiful? Shelly and Miranda notice that Bryce isn’t paying attenti

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And so happy? Shelly grabs Bryce’s arm.

dialogues.speaker: SHELLY
dialogues.text: Bryce, are you all right? You look like you’re possessed or something.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: What are you staring at?

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: (staring at Juli) Nothing. Miranda twists around to see what Bryce is looking at -- CLOSE ON JULI -- looking at Jon.  flippedldmay21 113. Bryce, almost in a daze, gets up from the table. And head toward Juli.

dialogues.speaker: SHELLY
dialogues.text: Bryce?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Where are you going? Shelly and Miranda stare.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Suddenly I realize Bryce was heading toward me.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It was like an invisible force was pulling me toward her --

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And he grabbed my hand -- Bryce grabs Juli’s hand and drags her away.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I grabbed her hand --

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: (to Bryce, confused) Hey --

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: What is it? What are you doing? On Juli and Bryce, together, in the middle of the cafeter

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: (quietly) Do you like him?

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Jon.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Of course I like him --

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: (intense) I mean “like” him?  flippedldmay21 114. Bryce takes her other hand.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I took her other hand.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He took my other hand.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It was like a compulsion or something --

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I just let him. I felt completely helpless.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: (to Bryce re: Jon) Well, no, I like him, but not like that --

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No. She said, No! (beat) My heart was pounding. On Bryce looking into Juli’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He was looking into my eyes --

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I was looking straight at her -- He pulls her toward him.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...-and then he was pulling me toward him...

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I pulled her toward me ... And leans in to kiss her.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: He was going to kiss me ...

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I had to kiss her. I didn’t care who saw.  flippedldmay21 115.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I couldn’t believe it. He was going to kiss me. I’d been waiting for this kiss most of my life and he was going to do it in front of everyone in the Multi-Purpose room? I panicked. I just panicked. Everyone is looking at them. Juli breaks away and runs out of the cafeteria.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She ran away from me.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I ran. He watches her go. All eyes on him.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She ran away like I was contaminated. And everyone was looking at me like I’d blown my entire circuit board. ON EVERYONE, staring at Bryce.

dialogues.speaker: SHELLY
dialogues.text: I want my money back, Bryce Loski.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Have you flipped?

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Yes. I have. I’ve flipped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juli races home on her bicycle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryce runs home.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I completely flipped. There was only one thing in my head and that was Juli Baker. How she just glowed. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: flippedldmay21 116. BRYCE (V.O.) (cont'd) How different she was from everybody else, but in a good way. She made them all seem ordinary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juli pulls in front of her bike and leaps off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trina is in the den, at her computer, as the front door s shut and Juli runs upstairs. Her bedroom door shuts with bang. Trina gets up. INT. JULI’S BEDROOM - DAY As Trina opens the door. Juli is lying face down on her bed.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: He tried to kiss me.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: Who did?

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Bryce.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: Oh. Bryce. Trina sits on the edge of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: It was totally humiliating. In front of everyone. And he’d just been sold at auction for $122.50 --

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: Not to you, I hope. That’s much too much to pay for a man --

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: To Shelly and Miranda and I was having lunch with Jon Trulock, who I bid on because I felt so bad for him, and then Bryce came over to me and tried to kiss me.  flippedldmay21 117. The doorbell rings.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Oh my god! That’s probably him. Don’t get it! Whatever you do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryce is ringing the doorbell. No answer. He bangs on the door. INT. JULI’S BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS Trina peeks out the window. TRINA’S POV As Bryce leaves to cross the street to his house.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: He’s leaving. He passes Juli’s bike, looks back at the Baker house.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: It’s not going to be easy to pretend you don’t live here.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: I know, I know!

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: We’re not moving, okay?

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: What am I going to do?

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. You used to like him.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Yes but I don’t like him any more. And last Friday night was the clincher.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: Absolutely. What about tea?  flippedldmay21 118.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Tea. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Trina puts the kettle on, Juli paces back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: I mean, I was over him. Totally over him.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: I know. The phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: It’s probably your dad. (answering) Hello. Hello, Bryce. On Juli, frantically shaking her head no.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: She is ... not available. I’m sorry. I will absolutely tell her you called. She hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Calling me? Now he’s calling me? I’ve lived across the street from him for five years and he’s never once called me. Trina starts to smile.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: This is not funny. I could end up like Mrs. Loski.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: I don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Why not?  flippedldmay21 119.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: Because Bryce is not his father. And by the way, Patsy’s having a very hard time -- she’s been over a couple of times this week to talk things over. I’m giving you peppermint. She hands Juli a cup of tea.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My advice to you is, don’t speak to Bryce ever again --

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: I’m not going to. Ever.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: Good. Because you might turn out to be wrong about him. And then you might have to marry him.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: Mom! I’m only thirteen.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA
dialogues.text: That's my point, honey. This is not about marrying the boy. Why don’t you listen to what he has to say? Don’t be so sure about him. People change. Especially when they’re young.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryce, worked up into a frenzy, is pacing in front of his grandfather, who is waiting patiently. Bryce stops pacing

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: I can’t tell you.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Fine. Don’t tell me.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: I tried to kiss her at that stupid Basket Boy lunch. I tried to kiss her. His grandfather starts to smile.  flippedldmay21 120.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: You did?

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: I was like possessed. But she ran away. She won’t talk to me.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Maybe she thinks it’s all a little sudden.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: But it’s not.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: It’s not?

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: No. I mean... it all started with that dumb newspaper article which I finally read and ... I don’t know, I’ve been crazy ever since. She doesn’t look the same, she doesn’t sound the same, she’s just ... different.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Maybe you’re the one who’s different.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: But she doesn’t know I’m different! How’s she going to know? She’1l never know.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Big problem.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: I need a grand gesture. That’s what I need. A grand gesture. What was yours, you know, with Grandma? What’d you do?

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: I gave her a key chain that said “I love Chet” on it.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: You’re kidding.  flippedldmay21 121.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: I am kidding. I did give her a key chain that said “I love Chet,” but that wasn’t the grand gesture. I made her a bookshelf. Renee loved books. She was a book-a- night girl. When you talked to her and she was reading, she didn’t hear a thing you said. And all her books were just stacked up everywhere, or on terrible shelves made of raw planks and bricks. So I took a class, and I learned all about dowels --

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: Dowels --

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: And I made her a bookshelf with not one nail in it. It was pine. I knew what I had to do. The idea popped into my head in a second and I couldn’t believe it took even a second, it was so obvious. On Bryce. He knows what he has to do. EXT. JULI’S HOUSE - NIGHT Bryce shows up in Juli’s front yard with a shovel and sta digging.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I had to ask Juli’s dad for permission. I mean you can’t just dig a giant hole in someone’s front yard without getting permission.

dialogues.speaker: A LITTLE LATER
dialogues.text: The hole is dug. Bryce is dirty and sweating. There’s a b pile of dirt and a bag of fertilizer.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And thank god for the twinkle lights or I wouldn’t have been able to see a thing. LATER: Bryce pushes a wheelbarrow, carrying a baby sycamo tree, its roots all wrapped in burlap, from his backyard to Juli’s.  flippedldmay21 122.

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It took me half the night and I was worried the whole time that Juli would wake up --

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: The tree is in the hole. Bryce is shoveling dirt around t roots...

dialogues.speaker: BRYCE
dialogues.text: But luck was on my side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juli comes downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt and Mike and Juli’s parents are in the kitchen. Matt and Mike look at each other in a really goofy way. Trina covers her mouth to keep from smiling. Robert buries his face in the newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: What’s going on? Everyone shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: JULI
dialogues.text: What is it? They all look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: You might want to take a look out front -- Matt and Mike nod. Trina is bursting.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Out front.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Front yard.  flippedldmay21 123.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Where to be. Juli starts out of the room. The family all stands to watch her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie walks to the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Juli comes out the front door. In the yard is the sycamore tree Bryce planted. Hanging o it, by a ribbon, is a card.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I knew the minute I saw it, from the shape of the leaves, from the texture of the trunk, that it was a sycamore tree. (continued) As Juli looks at the card and we see Bryce’s handwriting: “For Juli from Bryce.” On Juli as she starts to tear up for moment, wipes her ey

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O., CONTINUED)
dialogues.text: I guess there are times in your life when you realize that you've been absolutely wrong about someone, and it makes you so happy that you were wrong, so blissfully and amazingly happy you can’t even believe it -- (continued) She looks over at Bryce’s house. He’s in the window. He waves. She waves back.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O., CONTINUED)
dialogues.text: I mean, look at that tree. Some day it is going to be the most amazing, magnificent tree. (continued)  flippedldmay21 124. Juli starts to walk toward Bryce’s house.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O., CONTINUED)
dialogues.text: A hundred years from now, it’1l be miles in the air. (continued) Bryce comes out the front door of his house and walks tow Juli.

dialogues.speaker: JULI, (V.O., CONTINUED)
dialogues.text: And some day I bet that some kid will climb it, and it will change her life, the way it changed mine. Bryce and Juli meet in the middle of the street. They lean toward each other to kiss. Just before they actually kiss, crane up to the light.

dialogues.speaker: HOLD ON THE LIGHT
dialogues.text: And then, magically: Branches grow up into the frame from the bottom, spindly first, getting stronger and leafier and more bountiful un the branches of the sycamore tree fills the frame. PULL BACK ... MANY YEARS IN THE FUTURE ... The sycamore is now fully grown. A YOUNG GIRL begins to climb the tree. We see flashes of her as she climbs to th top, and sunshine streaks through the branches ... FADE OUT.
